awd_titl_txt: Successful Pathways to Graduation in Chemistry & Biochemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the "Successful Pathways to Graduation in Chemistry and Biochemistry" project is providing support to low-income students with demonstrated financial need and academic promise to succeed in STEM disciplines at the University of the Incarnate Word. The project is funding 15 scholarships lasting four years for students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in chemistry or biochemistry. In addition to financial support, students will participate in a comprehensive support program called "Cardinal Chemistry Scholars (C2S)". The C2S program will provide key resources to students, including peer and faculty mentoring, a supportive community, research experience, and training to develop the hard and soft skills they will need to be successful in college and in their professional careers. 

Students will be recruited from both high school and community college. In addition to scholarship assistance, this program will provide students with evidence-based curricular and co-curricular experiences designed to increase academic success as well as workplace and graduate school readiness. Students will participate in development activities focused on improving academic performance and confidence, building professional aptitude and reasoning abilities, and learning about career and educational opportunities. Industry partners will deliver career seminars, provide site tours, and offer students internship and employment opportunities. A structured peer-mentoring program will provide students with valuable academic guidance, help with selecting courses, and a chance to pass on the benefits of the program to STEM students who are newer to college. Experienced faculty mentors will guide students through registration, help them overcome challenges, support personal and professional development, explore career options, and guides students through the graduate admission process. Participants will engage in research on-campus to build skills in critical thinking, problem solving, and workplace readiness. They will also be encouraged and supported to pursue research experiences at major universities. Faculty will study the conditions under which such curricular and co-curricular activities prove effective and contribute to this body of knowledge through presentations and scholarly publications.

por.por_cntn:
This award was used to support students majoring in Chemistry or Biochemistry through the Cardinal Chemistry Scholars (C2S) Program.  Scholarships were provided to 33 students who demonstrated both potential for success in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields and financial need.  Another 12 students who did not qualify for scholarships but were deemed likely to benefit from the program also joined.  All students participated in a seminar course each semester that served as a hub for academic support and professional development activities. 

            Our goals for students were to 1) help them graduate and 2) find a rewarding job or get into a graduate school within a year.  One aspect of the grant, the Intellectual Merit, has been to study what makes the program effective in helping students meet these goals.  We found that students need to understand what it takes to succeed in college and what they gain from it.  A supportive community in which they feel at home is also important.  

            Students know they need good study skills to earn good grades, and our program provides training in these and related skills like time management and organization.  Students are often not aware that the skills they develop to succeed in classes are at least as important as the subjects they learn and that valuable lessons also come outside the classroom.  Helping people appreciate the skillsets they acquire, like critical thinking and communicating, strengthens their sense of purpose.  Students who recognize they are in school to find their path are more likely to take advantage of opportunities that will help guide and enhance their career outlooks, such as internships and extracurricular activities.  We discuss these ideas in the seminar course, but the best way to show students this ‘big picture’ is through the community experience the program helps provide, which includes informal peer mentoring and role modeling. 

            The presence of a supportive community has other benefits as well.  Some students know few people who have gone to college, which can leave them feeling lost and out of place.  Even students with an informed support system are likely to feel adrift in the new environment.  Being surrounded by peers that students identify with provides an important sense of belonging and great opportunities for experienced students to pass on skills and lessons learned to their peers.  This support improves students’ likelihood to graduate and be successful afterward.  These outcomes are the benefits to society, or Broader Impacts, of our program. 

            In terms of these Broader Impacts, our program has helped 10 students persist through graduation with degrees in Chemistry or Biochemistry and matriculate into STEM careers or STEM graduate programs.  The NSF program that provided the grant is specifically geared towards enhancing our STEM workforce, though we also count students who go on to other careers that are country needs such as healthcare and education as successes.  Another 11 people have graduated with STEM degrees and found careers or post-baccalaureate programs that, while not technically in STEM fields, are considered both good careers and areas of need for our workforce (healthcare and education, for example).  Three more students graduated in May 2024 but have not yet found their next step, and another five are still enrolled at our university.  Of the remaining 15, four graduated and two transferred to different schools, though the outcomes of these students are unknown.

            Another important set of Broader Impacts is the indirect benefits our program provided to our university community and wider society.  Students not involved in our program benefited indirectly through regular interactions with our scholars.  For example, students in our majors that were not involved in the program received academic and career advising from program participants who helped run our semiannual group advising sessions.  Our program provided a pipeline of qualified students to our tutoring center.  We organized trips to professional scientific conferences that involved students in other STEM fields.  Our scholars have engaged in community service projects within our institution and the greater community, including visiting local area high schools to promote college and STEM education.  The program collaborated with the Alumni Relations staff to host a panel discussion and mixer that brought together current students and alumni.  Faculty involved in the program became better at mentoring, advising, and promoting student success.  These faculty are involved in programs such as the First Year Engagement program that work towards our program goals across the university. 

            In summary, this award was used to support students pursuing careers in STEM and related fields through college and into a good job or a graduate program.  We identified important factors that contributed to student success: an appreciation of the purpose of college and a sense of belonging.  The Cardinal Chemistry Scholars Program fostered a community of students, faculty, staff, and alumni to address these needs. 

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2024
Modified by: Julian Davis
por.por_txt_cntn:
This award was used to support students majoring in Chemistry or Biochemistry through the Cardinal Chemistry Scholars (C2S) Program. Scholarships were provided to 33 students who demonstrated both potential for success in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields and financial need. Another 12 students who did not qualify for scholarships but were deemed likely to benefit from the program also joined. All students participated in a seminar course each semester that served as a hub for academic support and professional development activities.


 Our goals for students were to 1) help them graduate and 2) find a rewarding job or get into a graduate school within a year. One aspect of the grant, the Intellectual Merit,has been to study what makes the program effective in helping students meet these goals. We found that students need to understand what it takes to succeed in college and what they gain from it. A supportive community in which they feel at home is also important. 


 Students know they need good study skills to earn good grades, and our program provides training in these and related skills like time management and organization. Students are often not aware that the skills they develop to succeed in classes are at least as important as the subjects they learn and that valuable lessons also come outside the classroom. We discuss these ideas in the seminar course, but the best way to show students this big picture is through the community experience the program helps provide, which includes informal peer mentoring and role modeling.


 The presence of a supportive community has other benefits as well. Some students know few people who have gone to college, which can leave them feeling lost and out of place. Even students with an informed support system are likely to feel adrift in the new environment. Being surrounded by peers that students identify with provides an important sense of belonging and great opportunities for experienced students to pass on skills and lessons learned to their peers. This support improves students likelihood to graduate and be successful afterward. These outcomes are the benefits to society, or Broader Impacts,of our program.


 In terms of these Broader Impacts, our program has helped 10 students persist through graduation with degrees in Chemistry or Biochemistry and matriculate into STEM careers or STEM graduate programs. The NSF program that provided the grant is specifically geared towards enhancing our STEM workforce, though we also count students who go on to other careers that are country needs such as healthcare and education as successes. Another 11 people have graduated with STEM degrees and found careers or post-baccalaureate programs that, while not technically in STEM fields, are considered both good careers and areas of need for our workforce (healthcare and education, for example). Three more students graduated in May 2024 but have not yet found their next step, and another five are still enrolled at our university. Of the remaining 15, four graduated and two transferred to different schools, though the outcomes of these students are unknown.


 Another important set of Broader Impacts is the indirect benefits our program provided to our university community and wider society. For example, students in our majors that were not involved in the program received academic and career advising from program participants who helped run our semiannual group advising sessions. Our program provided a pipeline of qualified students to our tutoring center. We organized trips to professional scientific conferences that involved students in other STEM fields. Our scholars have engaged in community service projects within our institution and the greater community, including visiting local area high schools to promote college and STEM education. The program collaborated with the Alumni Relations staff to host a panel discussion and mixer that brought together current students and alumni. Faculty involved in the program became better at mentoring, advising, and promoting student success. These faculty are involved in programs such as the First Year Engagement program that work towards our program goals across the university.


 In summary, this award was used to support students pursuing careers in STEM and related fields through college and into a good job or a graduate program. We identified important factors that contributed to student success: an appreciation of the purpose of college and a sense of belonging. The Cardinal Chemistry Scholars Program fostered a community of students, faculty, staff, and alumni to address these needs.
